I first experienced this several years
ago when I moved to Parksville on
Vancouver Island in Canada one night not
long after I moved there I dreamed of a
small goose and this small goose invited
me to join it on a great journey over
the ocean and amazingly the next day
when I went for a walk and one of
Parksville 's beautiful beaches I
encountered a whole flock of these small
geese I later learned that they were
Brant geese and I learned that Brant
geese really do go on a great journey
over the ocean because each year
Brant geese migrate all the way from
Baja California up to the Canadian High
Arctic to raise their young and the
beaches of Parksville are the midway
point on the journey and they stop on
the beaches to feed to build up their
strength so that they can make it the
rest of the way to the Arctic and in a
beautiful piece of life's choreography
the Parksville beaches have a sumptuous
feast just waiting to replenish the
weary travelers because as the Brant
geese are migrating onto the parksville
beaches Pacific herring are migrating in
from the open ocean and gathering in
their spawning grounds that lie just off
the beaches the herring come in huge
and schools of fish sometimes several
kilometers long and when they reach
their spawning grounds each female
begins to release up to forty thousand
clear sticky eggs these eggs are rich in
protein and fat and that's what the
brand Keys come for you can hear the
hungry excitement in their voices long
before you see them flying
they come in small flocks singing their
hunger they come in great flocks singing
their hunger and as soon as they land
they begin to eat to eat while they're
walking and they eat while they're
talking they eat while they're swimming
in the water and they eat whether
standing in the beaches and it's not
just the bland geese who come to feed on
the eggs multitudes of gulls also arrive
for the feast and the gulls are joined
by diving ducks who are hungry for the
eggs and oyster catchers flamed up and
down the beaches in search of eggs and
Aboriginal people go out and gather the
eggs in their traditional way and gray
whales stop by on their way to Alaska
and they join the feast and then there
are the shore birds that dumblings the
sandpipers and the Sanderlings and
they're all hungry for the eggs but it's
not just the eggs that the animals come
for the eggs start to hatch into larvae
in about 10 to 14 days and there are
fish the salmon the perch and the hake
and they're all hungry for the larvae
and clouds of gulls go out on the water
and they're all hungry for the juvenile
Harry and hundreds and hundreds of sea
lions come in from the open ocean in a
great Dionysian celebration and they're
joined by hundreds of hairy fishermen
and hundreds of eagles
and they're all so hungry for the adult
herring
often when I witness this spectacle this
mystery plane I am struck by the immense
sacrifice that the herring made in the
service of life itself because of the
forty thousand eggs that each female may
release only four will reach adulthood
so this means that the other thirty nine
thousand nine hundred and ninety-six
eggs come into existence to nourish
other life forms to nourish the brand
geese and the gulls and the diving ducks
and the dumb ones and the sandpipers and
the Sanderlings and the whales and the
sea lions and the Eagles and the human
beings so much life coming in to life to
nourish other life forms
after a few weeks the Brandt geese grow
fat and strong from feasting on the eggs
they spend a few more days calmly
swimming in the quiet waters off the
beaches and then one day they begin to
rise up into the sky to continue their
journey to the Arctic where their young
will provide nourishment for hungry
arctic foxes and hungry herring gulls
and hungry parasitic Yeager's and a
whole host of other hungry creatures
[Music]
as I have stood still beside the Brandt
goofs my feelings and my dreams have
reached outward in all directions
becoming ever more inclusive reaching
out to embrace the relationships of the
salmon those same salmon who feasted
upon the herring larvae and grew strong
and went out on their own magnificent
journey into the Pacific Ocean until one
day they turned homeward to spawn in the
rivers of their birth like the gold
stream River just outside Victoria on
Vancouver Island each fall thousands of
salmon returned to spawn in the gold
stream River when the salmon reached
their spawning grounds each female uses
her tail to dig a series of depressions
in the gravel of the river bed and she
will deposit up to seven thousand round
pink eggs into these depressions the
male's fertilize the eggs as soon as
they're deposited and then the female
uses her tail once again to gently move
gravel over the nests of eggs
covering them in an attempt to protect
them from predators
and these eggs need all the protection
that they can get because during the
spawning season a whole host of other
creatures arrived at Gold stream to
feast on the salmon egg American dippers
position themselves on partially
submerged rocks and logs all along the
river bank and they courageously dive
into the river again and again in search
of eggs and then there are the gulls
they seem to come by the thousands and
they're also creative in finding the
salmon eggs the goes use their webbed
feet to churn up the gravel of the
riverbed to disturb the nests of eggs
and then they do these quick dives down
into the water to grab the eggs before
they're washed away by the current of
the river the American dippers and the
gulls and all of the other animals
consume about 5,600 of the 7,000 eggs
that each female may deposit and of the
eggs that do have only one in a thousand
will return to spawn the other 999 are
consumed by hungry seals and hungry sea
lions and hungry orca whales and hungry
dolphins and hungry bears and hungry
Eagles and hungry
human beings again so much light comes
in to life to nourish other life-forms
to nourish life itself
[Music]
and of course it's not only through
their eggs that the famine offer the
gift of life to others because after
they spawn the salmon begin to grow
weaker and weaker
they literally begin to disintegrate
before our eyes you often see it first
in their tattered dorsal fins and
eventually they begin to lose ground
against even the gentlest flow of the
river and one day they surrender resting
in the river until dragged to shore by
hungry gulls who are joined by hungry
mink and hungry otters and hungry
raccoons and hungry bears and hungry
Eagles also hungry for the flesh of the
salmon even the trees celebrate the
death of the salmon Gold stream has some
enormous trees huge western red cedars
and huge Douglas firs some of them six
hundred years old
huge broadleaf maples and huge black
cottonwoods and huge grand firs these
trees can only grow this big and live
this long because of the salmon the
Bears and all of the other animals drag
the salmon carcasses into the forest to
eat them and there's so many salmon they
only eat the good parts they
the leftovers for the bacteria and the
fungi and the insects who break down the
flesh of the salmon and make the
nutrients available to the trees up to
75% of the nitrogen in the gold stream
trees comes from the salmon it's no
wonder they call the gold stream forest
a salmon forest
